fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of an unknown woman, watercolour on vellum, painted by Nicholas Dixon, ca.1675.

fields.name: Special Exhibition of Portrait Miniatures on Loan at the South Kensington Museum

fields.physical_description:
Portrait of a woman, half-length, to front, head turned slightly to left, and wearing a decolletage dress decorated with pearls, a pearl earring in the left ear and a pearl necklace.  Features hatched in brown and sanguine, blended with gouache and some white heightening in the eyes, on a very pale carnation ground; hair in brown wash, hatched with darker colour and heightened with gouache, over the carnation; dress in pale blue wash overlaid with darker colour and heightened with white; chemise and pearls in grey wash, heightened with white and with touches of grey and black; a touch of gold in the ear-ring; background in green-brown washes, hatched diagonally top right to lower left; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. 

<u>Frame: </u>Seventeenth-century oval gold locket, convex back, the sides with a single narrow channel, flaring out to the bezel, which holds the flat glass by its rounded edges; at the base of the oval there are two dark marks and evidence of filing, which suggests that the locket may originally have had a hinged front cover; the hanger of D-section grooved down the middle, tooled on the ridges and with two narrow outer flanges, bifurcating into diminishing spirals of three turns; below the hanger, and unusually well integrated with it, there is an arrangement of engraved scroll-and-line ornament.
fields.title: An Unknown Woman
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.public_access_description:
The word ‘miniature’ describes a technique of painting in watercolour rather than the size of a painting. Miniature painting developed as a separate art in the 16th century and in Britain it became predominantly a portrait art.
This miniature was formerly thought to be of Louise de Keroualle, Duchess of Portsmouth and one of Charles II’s mistresses. Although not Louise, she must be a lady of the court. Nicholas Dixon was at the height of his fortunes at this time having succeeded Samuel Cooper to the coveted post of King’s limner in 1672. The bold and unusually elaborate execution is indicative of the way his style adapted to his clientele at court. The use in particular of gold in rendering the gold of the earring was unusual in late 17th-century miniatures when yellow paint was generally used to simulate the desired effect. The whole effect, extravagant in its colour and palpably sensuous in its appeal surely indicates that the sitter was special, perhaps one of the ladies close to the monarch. 

In the 1670s flesh was in fashion and Dixon was clearly influenced by Peter Lely’s round faced figurative style and his almond shaped, elongated eyes, half-closed, which according to one commentator ‘convey languorous lasciviousness’. These mannerisms were particularly noticeable in Lely’s portraits of the Beauties of Charles II’s court, painted 1666–8. At this time, however, it was Charles II’s mistresses who led the way at court in terms of fashion, and not the Queen as had been true in Charles I’s day. This miniature is a particularly arch example of this tendency.

Full citation: “Unknown Woman ” c.1675 P4-1942 Oval 86 x 68 mm Features hatched in brown and sanguine, blended with gouache and some white heightening in the eyes, on a very pale carnation ground; hair in brown wash, hatched with darker colour and heightened with gouache, over the carnation; dress in pale blue wash overlaid with darker colour and heightened with white; chemise and pearls in grey wash, heightened with white and with touches of grey and black; a touch of gold in the ear-ring; background in green-brown washes, hatched diagonally top right to lower left; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Losses in the forehead and upper cheek, the former retouched with zinc-white; some other retouches in the background upper left; other small losses and abrasions. Signed: Lower centre left, in black; ND (see C in Appendix 2). Frame: Seventeenth-century oval gold locket, convex back, the sides with a single narrow channel, flaring out to the bezel, which holds the flat glass by its rounded edges; at the base of the oval there are two dark marks and evidence of filing, which suggests that the locket may originally have had a hinged front cover; the hanger of D-section grooved down the middle, tooled on the ridges and with two narrow outer flanges, bifurcating into diminishing spirals of three turns; below the hanger, and unusually well integrated with it, there is an arrangement of engraved scroll-and-line ornament. Provenance: Buccleuch Collection; purchased as part of a group by the NACF, 1942, and presented to the Museum. Exhibited: South Kensington 1865, no. 1591 (as by Nathaniel Dixon); National Gallery, NACF Exhibition, November 1945 - February 1946 (unnumbered); New Haven etc. 1981-2, no. 58. Literature: Mackay 1896, p. 90, no. 15 (as by 'Nathaniel Dixon') ; Foster 1914-16, vol. II, p. 101, no. 90; Kennedy 1917, p. 38, either P15 or P23 (Kennedy muddled these Mackay numbers, and opined that one of these Signed Dixon miniatures was by the artist he knew as Paolo Carandini, i.e., Peter Cross); Illustrated London News, 18 April 1942, repro. p. 478; Whinney and Millar 1957, p. 98n.; Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 16; Murdoch 1981, p. 155, col. pl. 24b; Reynolds 1988, p. 81, fig. 45. The miniature was identified in the Buccleuch Collection as a portrait of Louise de Keroualle, Duchess of Portsmouth (the mistress of Charles II). Carl Winter expressed his doubts when cataloguing the recently acquired miniatures from the Buccleuch Collection in 1942. (1) The identification has attracted no recent support, and there have been no other suggestions. Yet the lady, painted in the mid-1670s, is likely to have been of the Court. Dixon was at the height of his fortune as successor to Cooper's King's Limnership, and the miniature is elaborately finished and of superb quality. Does the fact that it has retained its original gold locket indicate an uninterrupted family provenance? If so, it could have descended from Anne (1651-1732), suo jure Countess, and subsequently Duchess of Buccleuch, the widow of James Scott, Duke of Monmouth (executed 15 July 1685) and could represent her. Perhaps more probably, in view of the idiom of the portrait, it could have descended from Ralph Montagu, 3rd Earl and 1st Duke of Montagu, who married 24 August 1673 as his first wife Elizabeth (1646-1690), widow of Joceline Percy; 11th Earl of Northumberland (d.May 1670). She was the youngest daughter of Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton and was very much one of the Court beauties. She was thought to be a candidate for the hand of the Duke of York after the death of the Duchess (Anne Hyde, 31 March 1671). ‘Shee, having mist her ayme of Dutchess of York, will not long continue a widdow’. (2) She turned down, among others, the young William, Duke of Somerset (1652-1671) and is said to have avoided the King's bed only by going to Paris, where she was wooed by Montagu, the British Ambassador and architect of the recently Signed secret Treaty of Dover (1670). She was worth £6,000 a year, and the match greatly forwarded Montagu's career. The standard portrait of her at this period is by Lely at Windsor. (3) Judging likenesses of these fashionable beauties is, however, extremely hazardous, and the possibility that Elizabeth was the sitter for this miniature can only be taken as arising from the possible Montagu provenance. A considerable nucleus of the Buccleuch miniatures came from Montagu House, passing with the rest of the property at the marriage (2 May 1767) of Henry Scott, 3rd Duke of Buccleuch, to Elizabeth (1743-1827), daughter and heiress of George Brudenell, 4th Earl of Cardigan, by his wife Mary, sole heiress of'[ohn, the last Duke of Montagu. Elizabeth, however, seems to have purchased miniatures to add to the Collection, so that when they were finally inherited by her grandson Walter Francis (1806-1884), the 5th Duke, they were already a mixed bag. The 5th Duke was a serious connoisseur and added substantially to the Collection, as did his son William (1831-1914), the 6th Duke. Many of the miniatures in the Collection have clearly been through the trade and have been re-framed or otherwise attended to in their physical state - see for example the Flatman Self-Portrait (Cat. No.130). When sold by their original owners (or when a family is otherwise needing to raise money), miniatures tend to lose their gold settings, so the nearly intact gold locket on this miniature does suggest that it may have been part of the Montagu nucleus rather than the Buccleuch purchases for the Collection. 1 MS notes in the departmental file. 2 Letters addressed to Sir ]oseph Williamson While Plenipotentiary at the Congress in Cologne…1673 and 1674, ed. W D Christie, etc., Camden Society Publications, NS, vol. VIII (1874), p. 164. Millar 1963, vol.I, pp. 125-6, no. 261, pl. 114; see also Anna Jameson, The Beauties of the Court of King Charles the Second (1833), pp. 165-174." Victoria and Albert Museum, Department of Engraving, Illustration and Design and Department of Paintings, Accessions 1942, London: HMSO, 1955. The full text of the record is as follows: DIXON, Nicholas (worked 1667-1708) Miniature portrait of a lady, said to be Louise Renée de Kéroualle, Duchess of Portsmouth (1649-1734). Signed with monogram ND. On parchment on card. Oval. P.4-1942 Given by the National Art-Collections Fund Note: This miniature was formerly in the collection of the Duke of Buccleuch.'
